headline: Asia shares lower after sharp Wall Street losses on AI-related worries
summary: Asia shares were trading lower Friday, tracking sharp Wall Street losses on a sell-off of technology-related stocks that investors fear could lose out from artificial intelligence disruptions.  “Our sense remains that a sustained reversal of tech outperformance would require a big slide in tech itself,” Thomas Mathews, head of markets for Asia Pacific at Capital Economics wrote in a recent note.

headline: World shares mixed after sharp Wall Street losses on AI-related worries
summary: World shares were mixed on Friday, following sharp Wall Street losses on a sell-off of technology-related stocks that investors fear could lose out from artificial intelligence disruptions.  The S&P 500 fell for its second-worst day since Thanksgiving, dropping 1.6%, or 108.71, to 6,832.76, but it's still near an all-time high that was set last month.

content.title: World shares mixed after sharp Wall Street losses on AI-related worries

The S&P 500 fell for its second-worst day since Thanksgiving, dropping 1.6%, or 108.71, to 6,832.76, but it's still near an all-time high that was set last month.

headline: Walmart, economic data await investors confronting AI 'whack-a-mole'
summary: U.S. stock investors will be on guard next week for further volatility induced by fears of artificial intelligence disruption as they also assess the durability of a rotation beneath the market's surface, along with upcoming earnings from Walmart ‌and fresh economic data.  After sinking shares of software companies this month, fears that new AI tools will disrupt various industries, including insurance, wealth management and transportation, slammed stocks this week.  "It's all this whack-a-mole ​game of trying to figure out what AI is going to destroy next in a world where you can invent a narrative, because this technology is so new that artificial intelligence is likely going to end up eating the whole world," said Art Hogan, chief market strategist at B Riley Wealth.

content.title: Walmart, economic data await investors confronting AI 'whack-a-mole'

"It's all this whack-a-mole ​game of trying to figure out what AI is going to destroy next in a world where you can invent a narrative, because this technology is so new that artificial intelligence is likely going to end up eating the whole world," said Art Hogan, chief market strategist at B Riley Wealth.

headline: Vista Equity explores $1 billion-plus sale of AlertMedia, sources say
summary: Vista Equity Partners is exploring a $1 billion-plus sale of its emergency ‌communications software provider AlertMedia, according to people familiar with ‌the matter.  Vista has hired bankers at JPMorgan to sell the company, ​a process that is in the early stages, the people said, requesting anonymity as the discussions are confidential.  Vista Equity and JPMorgan declined to comment, while AlertMedia did not respond ‌to a request ⁠for comments.

content.title: Vista Equity explores $1 billion-plus sale of AlertMedia, sources say

Vista Equity and JPMorgan declined to comment, while AlertMedia did not respond ‌to a request ⁠for comments.

headline: Consumer spending behavior is evolving: Ibotta survey
summary: Even as overall inflation cools, food prices are still rising faster, keeping pressure on household budgets. Meanwhile, Ibotta's (IBTA) recent "State of the Spend" survey shows 62% of consumers now prioritize price over brand, 68% discover products through promotions, and more shoppers are making in-store decisions based on deals. Ibotta founder and CEO Bryan Leach chats with Market Catalysts host Julie Hyman to discuss the data, how retailers like Walmart (WMT) and Dollar General (DG) are benefiting as brands, how consumers are using digital promotions, and more. For more expert analysis on currency markets and global investing trends, watch the full segment on Market Catalysts.

content.title: Consumer spending behavior is evolving: Ibotta survey
content.description:
Even as overall inflation cools, food prices are still rising faster, keeping pressure on household budgets.

Meanwhile, Ibotta's (IBTA) recent "State of the Spend" survey shows 62% of consumers now prioritize price over brand, 68% discover products through promotions, and more shoppers are making in-store decisions based on deals.

Ibotta founder and CEO Bryan Leach chats with Market Catalysts host Julie Hyman to discuss the data, how retailers like Walmart (WMT) and Dollar General (DG) are benefiting as brands, how consumers are using digital promotions, and more.

For more expert analysis on currency markets and global investing trends, watch the full segment on Market Catalysts.

headline: Exxon, Walmart and 9 Other Stocks That Are Soaring Because Cash Is King Again
summary: With Wall Street worried artificial intelligence is coming for white-collar jobs, hard-hat and other “real economy” stocks are suddenly fashionable again.  It has been a difficult few weeks for stocks that look vulnerable to AI disruption, with selloffs rocking everything from software to financials to media.  “The relative winner is asset-heavy cash returners,” wrote 22V Research President Dennis DeBusschere in a note Friday, highlighting strong performance of materials, energy, real estate investment trusts, and staples—all sectors that have outperformed the  , which is essentially flat in 2026.

content.title: Exxon, Walmart and 9 Other Stocks That Are Soaring Because Cash Is King Again
content.summary: With Wall Street worried artificial intelligence is coming for white-collar jobs, hard-hat and other “real economy” stocks are suddenly fashionable again.  It has been a difficult few weeks for stocks that look vulnerable to AI disruption, with selloffs rocking everything from software to financials to media.  “The relative winner is asset-heavy cash returners,” wrote 22V Research President Dennis DeBusschere in a note Friday, highlighting strong performance of materials, energy, real estate investment trusts, and staples—all sectors that have outperformed the  , which is essentially flat in 2026.

headline: Business Lookahead: Giddy Up
summary:
STORY: From bellwether Walmart reporting earnings... to new economic data out of the UK... these are the stories to watch in business and finance in the coming week.

:: The trillion dollar club

Fresh off hitting $1 trillion in market value, Walmart posts quarterly results on Thursday.

Walmart's report offers a glimpse into consumer spending after recent data showed December U.S. retail sales were unexpectedly flat.

A surprisingly strong employment report for January eased some concerns about economic weakening.

Economic reports in the coming week include the advance reading of fourth-quarter GDP, a monthly consumer sentiment survey, and the personal consumption expenditures price index, a key inflation measure.

:: Heavy metals

Europe's four largest mining companies report earnings in the coming week.

Copper, gold, silver and other precious metals all recently hit records - but the January rally has given way to a sharp February sell-off.

Last month's rally boosted the market values of Rio Tinto, Glencore, Anglo American and Antofagasta.

Their earnings will test whether the momentum can be sustained.

:: UK economic data 

UK labor market data and inflation readings will provide fresh fodder for markets, even though investors are still digesting the fallout from the recent government instability.

Labor market numbers due on Tuesday will show if a gradual cooling of wage growth has continued.

Then, January inflation data comes Wednesday.

The political turmoil has set a tense backdrop, leaving markets highly sensitive to data swings. Fitch is also due to review its UK rating on Friday.

content.title: Business Lookahead: Giddy Up

headline: Walmart Earnings, GDP, Inflation Figures: What to Watch Next Week
summary: Investors face a holiday-shortened week featuring Federal Reserve speakers and economic data. Walmart earnings will provide insight into the health of the U.S. consumer. The market will parse a significant batch of data at the end of next week—including an advance look at fourth-quarter GDP and the personal-consumption expenditures price index—to gauge the economy's momentum and inflation.
